body:
> This differs from the behavior of other objects such as numbers, strings, and process objects, which throw when `Count` is accessed.

They do not throw:

![ss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/78153320/120881174-0d333680-c5d8-11eb-9430-dc3456c99989.png)

Sorry if I didn't clarify enough in the issue description. In your example, I wouldn't expect any of those to throw in strict mode either. `PSCustomObject` doesn't throw, and that's the subject of this issue. Strings won't throw when accessing `Length`, since that's a valid property on strings. They will throw when accessing `Count`, though. `(gps).Count` doesn't throw, since `gps` returns an array, and arrays have a `Count` property.

My reasoning behind creating the issue is that most objects that don't have `Count` (or `Length`) properties throw in strict mode when you try to access those properties. `PSCustomObject` doesn't throw, however, which seems like inconsistent behavior.

Does that make sense?

```powershell
PS>Set-StrictMode -Version Latest
PS>'aaa'.Count
PropertyNotFoundException: The property 'Count' cannot be found on this object. Verify that the property exists.
PS>(gps)[0].Count
PropertyNotFoundException: The property 'Count' cannot be found on this object. Verify that the property exists.
PS>(4).Count
PropertyNotFoundException: The property 'Count' cannot be found on this object. Verify that the property exists.
PS>
```

> (gps).Count doesn't throw, since gps returns an array, and arrays have a Count property.

I don't think that is true, `Array` does not have a `Count` property, they just have `Length` so this is another edge case where `Count` is present. I don't really have any strong feelings either way though, Strict Mode is mostly a curiosity for me and not something I've used successfully in the past.

From using `Get-Member`, it seems like arrays have both a `Count` and a `Length` property, although I might be missing something:

```
PS> Get-Member -InputObject @(1, 2, 3)

   TypeName: System.Object[]

Name           MemberType            Definition
----           ----------            ----------

However, `PSCustomObject` doesn't have a `Count` property:

```
PS> Get-Member -InputObject ([pscustomobject]@{a=1; b=2})

   TypeName: System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject

Name        MemberType   Definition
----        ----------   ----------
Equals      Method       bool Equals(System.Object obj)
GetHashCode Method       int GetHashCode()
GetType     Method       type GetType()
ToString    Method       string ToString()
a           NoteProperty int a=1
b           NoteProperty int b=2
```

Neither do strings or numbers (`Int32` in this case):

```

> it seems like arrays have both a Count and a Length property

I think this was left for backward compatibility with Windows Powershell, where `Count` was an alias for `Length` and very many scripts use both of them.

It’s not documented in the [Array](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.array?view=net-5.0) type. While it appears as an adapted property it’s still not part of the underlying type AFAIK.

> It’s not documented in the [Array](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.array?view=net-5.0) type. While it appears as an adapted property it’s still not part of the underlying type AFAIK.

It looks like it is documented there. Under "Explicit Interface Implementations" the page lists `ICollection.Count`.

`Count` tends to persist on most PS objects because it is an automatic property. If you check the `Count` property of any non-array it will generally give you the result `1`, except if the value you're checking is `$null`, when it may be `0`.

This is so that users don't have to be hypervigilant over whether a given pipeline result is one or multiple items, and can simply check `Count`.

Not sure how consistently it works in strict mode, though.

Engine-supplied members such as `.Count`, `.Length`, `.psobject`, `ForEach()`, .... now have an official name:  [_intrinsic members_](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_Intrinsic_Members).

It makes much more sense to make them _consistently_ available _irrespective of strict mode_.

This is already true for most of them, but inexplicably not for `.Count` and `.Length` (in general), despite their tremendous usefulness in unified handling of scalars and collections, as mentioned by @vexx32.

In short: Fix #2798, and everyone will live happily ever after.

`Set-StrictMode` isn't heavily used anyway, but at least for me it was #2798 that prevented me from ever using `Set-StrictMode -Version 2` or higher.

Here's a quick demonstration of the inconsistency:

```powershell
# .psobject, .ForEach(), scalar indexing already work in all strict modes, .Count does not.
PS> & { Set-StrictMode -version Latest; ('foo').psobject; ('foo').ForEach({"[$_]"}); (42)[0]; ('foo').Count }


BaseObject          : foo
Members             : {char Chars(int index) {get;}, int Length {get;}, Remove, Replace…}
Properties          : {int Length {get;}}
Methods             : {Remove, Replace, Split, Substring…}
ImmediateBaseObject : foo
TypeNames           : {System.String, System.Object}

[foo]
42

PropertyNotFoundException: The property 'Count' cannot be found on this object. Verify that the property exists.
```
